column5: Hey guys it's my first winter fly fishing. i was wondering if any of you had any tips regarding how to prevent the guides from icing .  I'm thinking there isn't a way to prevent that. maybe just minimize the amount of ice forms. any help would be greatly appreciated thanks in advance tight lines
ice off paste there's a bunch of companies that sell it and any shop that caters to fly/float fishing will carry it
cool thanks for the tip , any brand in particular?

I'm cheap I use lipchap instead of just buying the right stuff and lipchap doesn't work that good I'm going to try vaseline tomorrow to see if it's any better but not expecting it to be any better ask your tackle shop they wil know which is better.

You have to do more than just your line guides. Apply bees wax to your line and to your guides. This will repel water for a fairly long time. Easy to apply, just strip your line through it in your hand. Just a FYI... Bees wax is easily found at any lumber or hardware store, even Canadian Tire. Wax setting seals for toilets is made from bees wax.
The best cure for icing of the guides during winter is a trip to BIMINI for some bonefishing!!!!!
I had the same problem today when I was learning to fly fish at Bluffers park!

I've found two methods that work well.  First, a little vasoline on the upper eyes and then patience.  Every three to four casts I de-ice with a cotton rag I have attached to my vest.  Just make sure you remove the ice in an upward motion.  My buddy snapped his tip the other day by sliding his rag downward.
